2.1Â RulesÂ ofÂ theÂ GameÂ TheÂ rulesÂ ofÂ theÂ gameÂ shapeÂ theÂ incentivesÂ andÂ practicesÂ ofÂ theÂ individualÂ actorsÂ andÂ organizationsÂ involvedÂ inÂ theÂ deliveryÂ ofÂ socialÂ protectionÂ benefitsÂ andÂ services,Â includingÂ policymakers,Â serviceÂ providers,Â programÂ managers,Â andÂ beneficiaries.Â ClearÂ andÂ transparentÂ rulesÂ areÂ importantÂ prerequisitesÂ forÂ accountabilityÂ relationshipsÂ toÂ workÂ atÂ allÂ levelsÂ ofÂ aÂ socialÂ protectionÂ system,Â orÂ program.Â IfÂ roles,Â responsibilities,Â andÂ incentivesÂ areÂ notÂ clearlyÂ defined,Â controlÂ andÂ enforcementÂ mechanismsÂ cannotÂ operateÂ effectively.Â BuildingÂ broadÂ credibilityÂ amongÂ beneficiariesÂ andÂ otherÂ stakeholdersÂ requiresÂ clear,Â transparent,Â andÂ enforceableÂ rules,Â withÂ definedÂ oversightÂ institutions.Â

TheÂ formalÂ rulesÂ ofÂ theÂ gameÂ areÂ setÂ throughÂ legalÂ andÂ regulatoryÂ frameworks,Â includingÂ nationalÂ constitutions,Â laws,Â andÂ regulationsÂ governingÂ theÂ socialÂ protectionÂ system.Â AtÂ thisÂ levelÂ theÂ rulesÂ ofÂ theÂ gameÂ referÂ toÂ theÂ mainÂ lawsÂ governingÂ rightsÂ toÂ socialÂ protectionÂ andÂ accessÂ toÂ services,Â andÂ ultimatelyÂ reflectÂ theÂ socialÂ contractÂ inÂ aÂ givenÂ country.Â AtÂ theÂ programÂ level,Â rulesÂ referÂ toÂ theÂ specificÂ laws,Â regulations,Â operationalÂ manuals,Â andÂ guidelinesÂ thatÂ setÂ theÂ variousÂ processesÂ andÂ activitiesÂ ofÂ aÂ program.Â TheÂ discussionÂ inÂ thisÂ sectionÂ focusesÂ mainlyÂ onÂ formalÂ rules,Â asÂ theseÂ areÂ theÂ mainÂ entryÂ pointsÂ forÂ BankÂ involvementÂ inÂ socialÂ protection,Â includingÂ socialÂ assistance.Â
SocialÂ assistanceÂ programsÂ canÂ beÂ vulnerableÂ toÂ politicalÂ interference,Â inequities,Â politicalÂ economyÂ risks,Â eliteÂ capture,Â andÂ corruption.Â InÂ manyÂ casesÂ theseÂ risksÂ areÂ generatedÂ orÂ facilitatedÂ byÂ theÂ absenceÂ ofÂ clearÂ andÂ transparentÂ rulesÂ ofÂ theÂ game,Â especiallyÂ regardingÂ eligibilityÂ forÂ programs,Â establishmentÂ ofÂ servicesÂ andÂ benefitÂ levels,Â paymentÂ arrangements,Â andÂ programÂ financing.Â InÂ orderÂ toÂ minimizeÂ risksÂ andÂ makeÂ accountabilityÂ mechanismsÂ workÂ inÂ socialÂ protectionÂ programs,Â threeÂ basicÂ principlesÂ areÂ importantÂ forÂ theÂ rulesÂ ofÂ theÂ game:Â (i)Â clarityÂ andÂ simplicity,Â (ii)Â transparency,Â andÂ (iii)Â consistencyÂ inÂ applicationÂ acrossÂ andÂ withinÂ programs,Â includingÂ withÂ agreedâ€?uponÂ programÂ objectivesÂ (seeÂ FigureÂ 2).Â Clear,Â simple,Â transparent,Â andÂ consistentÂ rulesÂ contributeÂ toÂ reducedÂ roomÂ forÂ bias,Â arbitrariness,Â error,Â fraud,Â andÂ corruptionÂ andÂ toÂ increasedÂ predictabilityÂ ofÂ benefits.Â TheyÂ enableÂ theÂ functioningÂ ofÂ accountabilityÂ mechanismsÂ andÂ canÂ enhanceÂ theÂ effectivenessÂ andÂ efficiencyÂ ofÂ interventionsÂ throughÂ reducingÂ exclusionÂ andÂ inclusionÂ errors.Â

Social protection programs and social assistance programs in particular are often organizationally complex, involving multiple government actors, systems, and processes. In many countries, social protection programs have evolved and been added to over time, with new programs created and existing programs modified and expanded. As a result, social protection systems and programs frequently lack an overall strategic vision and a clear institutional structure. Social assistance programs are also multi-sectoral and may fall under the responsibility of multiple ministries and government agencies. They also can involve local governments. In many cases, their objectives are interrelated and sometimes contradictory and this translates into increasingly complex systems characterized by cross- incentives. Inappropriately defined roles can generate perverse incentives or, in the case of overlapping roles, make accountability unclear. The lack of coordination across implementing institutions poses risks for program effectiveness and can blur accountability if roles and responsibilities are not clearly defined or inappropriately defined.

DatabaseÂ crosschecks.Â TheseÂ checksÂ examineÂ whetherÂ theÂ beneficiaryÂ informationÂ inÂ theÂ programÂ databaseÂ isÂ consistentÂ withÂ informationÂ inÂ otherÂ publicÂ databasesÂ (e.g.,Â taxÂ recordsÂ andÂ civilÂ registries)Â andÂ canÂ identifyÂ ineligibleÂ beneficiariesÂ orÂ individualsÂ receivingÂ inappropriateÂ benefits.Â ForÂ example,Â Brazilâ€™sÂ BolsaÂ FamÃ­liaÂ usesÂ internalÂ andÂ externalÂ crosschecksÂ ofÂ theÂ CadastroÂ ÃšnicoÂ dataÂ toÂ identifyÂ duplicateÂ registrations,Â scanÂ forÂ consistencyÂ andÂ completeness,Â andÂ verifyÂ incomeÂ andÂ otherÂ informationÂ againstÂ otherÂ databases.Â ForÂ example,Â asÂ aÂ checkÂ onÂ consistencyÂ ofÂ information,Â ifÂ aÂ personâ€™sÂ reportedÂ consumptionÂ isÂ 20%Â higherÂ thanÂ theÂ selfâ€?reportedÂ income,Â theÂ caseÂ isÂ sentÂ forÂ furtherÂ verificationÂ (LindertÂ etÂ al.Â 2007).Â
SpotÂ checks.Â OneÂ ofÂ theÂ goodÂ practicesÂ forÂ increasingÂ accountabilityÂ isÂ toÂ conductÂ periodicÂ thirdâ€?partyÂ reviewsÂ ofÂ keyÂ aspectsÂ ofÂ programÂ designÂ andÂ implementation.Â TheseÂ reviews,Â calledÂ spotÂ checks,Â areÂ rapidÂ evaluationÂ instrumentsÂ thatÂ seekÂ toÂ determineÂ theÂ quality,Â effectiveness,Â andÂ efficiencyÂ ofÂ theÂ programÂ inÂ someÂ ofÂ theÂ followingÂ areas:Â design,Â operationalÂ management,Â institutionalÂ structure,Â payments,Â andÂ theÂ monitoringÂ system.Â SpotÂ checksÂ provideÂ informationÂ aboutÂ theÂ executionÂ ofÂ differentÂ programÂ processes,Â whichÂ canÂ serveÂ asÂ theÂ basisÂ forÂ aÂ deeperÂ analysisÂ ofÂ programÂ operationÂ atÂ differentÂ levelsÂ andÂ amongÂ theÂ stakeholdersÂ involved.Â BeyondÂ theirÂ technicalÂ merits,Â spotÂ checksÂ enhanceÂ governance,Â transparency,Â andÂ accountabilityÂ asÂ theyÂ assessÂ andÂ validateÂ aÂ wideÂ rangeÂ ofÂ actionsÂ andÂ playersÂ involvedÂ inÂ theÂ programÂ delivery.Â SpotÂ checksÂ canÂ alsoÂ preventÂ fraudÂ andÂ corruptionÂ throughÂ deterrence.Â Â

57Â InterviewsÂ wereÂ conductedÂ everyÂ sixÂ monthsÂ inÂ aÂ randomlyÂ selectedÂ sampleÂ ofÂ 20Â municipalities.Â ProgramÂ staffÂ interviewÂ participants,Â programÂ officials,Â andÂ localÂ governmentsÂ usingÂ structuredÂ questionnaires,Â coveringÂ 400Â indicatorsÂ ofÂ criticalÂ programÂ aspectsÂ includingÂ enrollment,Â verificationÂ ofÂ complianceÂ withÂ conditionalities,Â payment,Â appeals,Â andÂ participationÂ inÂ andÂ qualityÂ ofÂ healthÂ educationÂ sessions.Â ResultsÂ indicateÂ whichÂ aspectsÂ ofÂ theÂ programÂ workÂ well,Â whereÂ thereÂ isÂ regionalÂ variationÂ inÂ programÂ management,Â andÂ whatÂ changesÂ inÂ procedures,Â staff,Â training,Â orÂ otherÂ inputsÂ mayÂ beÂ needed.Â

58Â GrievanceÂ RedressÂ Â GrievanceÂ redressÂ mechanismsÂ (GRMs),Â alsoÂ knownÂ asÂ complaintsâ€?handling,Â referÂ toÂ theÂ formalÂ institutionsÂ andÂ channelsÂ thatÂ captureÂ beneficiaryÂ complaintsÂ orÂ grievancesÂ relatedÂ toÂ targeting,Â serviceÂ delivery,Â orÂ otherÂ programÂ functions,Â andÂ provideÂ redress.Â GrievanceÂ redressÂ isÂ anÂ importantÂ elementÂ ofÂ managingÂ aÂ targetedÂ program,Â particularlyÂ whenÂ cashÂ isÂ involved.Â GrievanceÂ redressÂ mechanismsÂ canÂ beÂ importantÂ forÂ mitigatingÂ inclusionÂ andÂ exclusionÂ errorsÂ andÂ forÂ monitoringÂ corruption.Â GRMsÂ forÂ managingÂ targetingÂ areÂ alsoÂ foundÂ inÂ socialÂ protectionÂ programsÂ thatÂ disburseÂ targetedÂ grantsÂ toÂ poorÂ communities,Â suchÂ asÂ socialÂ fundsÂ andÂ otherÂ communityâ€?drivenÂ developmentÂ programs.Â Â

SocialÂ audits.Â SocialÂ auditsÂ areÂ participatoryÂ processesÂ inÂ whichÂ aÂ programÂ offersÂ information,Â andÂ beneficiariesÂ organizedÂ inÂ variousÂ waysÂ (e.g.,Â socialÂ auditÂ committee)Â provideÂ feedbackÂ onÂ theÂ implementationÂ ofÂ theÂ programÂ inÂ theirÂ communitiesÂ andÂ provideÂ suggestionsÂ forÂ improvement.Â InÂ manyÂ cases,Â beneficiaries,Â communities,Â orÂ theÂ generalÂ populationÂ reviewÂ officialÂ recordsÂ inÂ orderÂ toÂ determineÂ whetherÂ reportedÂ expendituresÂ reflectÂ moneyÂ beingÂ spentÂ onÂ theÂ ground.Â
ForÂ example,Â PanamaÂ hasÂ pilotedÂ aÂ participatoryÂ socialÂ auditÂ toÂ captureÂ beneficiaryÂ perceptionsÂ ofÂ itsÂ healthÂ program,Â theÂ ProgramaÂ deÂ AtencionÂ IntegralÂ deÂ ServiciosÂ deÂ SaludÂ (PAISS).Â RepresentativesÂ ofÂ existingÂ civilÂ societyÂ groupsÂ inÂ eachÂ communityÂ areÂ selectedÂ toÂ beÂ membersÂ ofÂ aÂ socialÂ auditÂ committeeÂ andÂ areÂ trainedÂ byÂ regionalÂ healthÂ staffÂ toÂ beÂ certifiedÂ asÂ socialÂ auditors.Â TheÂ socialÂ auditorsÂ interviewÂ severalÂ beneficiariesÂ inÂ theirÂ communitiesÂ onÂ topicsÂ suchÂ asÂ perceptionsÂ aboutÂ healthÂ services,Â whetherÂ healthÂ staffÂ areÂ present,Â andÂ whetherÂ theyÂ receiveÂ anÂ explanationÂ ofÂ theÂ servicesÂ provided.Â OnÂ anÂ annualÂ basis,Â theÂ socialÂ auditors,Â regionalÂ andÂ localÂ MinistryÂ ofÂ HealthÂ staff,Â andÂ NGOÂ providersÂ meetÂ toÂ discussÂ theÂ findingsÂ fromÂ theÂ surveys.Â TheÂ groupÂ developsÂ aÂ commonÂ actionÂ planÂ toÂ solveÂ theÂ serviceÂ provisionÂ problemsÂ thatÂ wereÂ identifiedÂ duringÂ theÂ socialÂ audit.Â ResultsÂ ofÂ theÂ socialÂ auditÂ determineÂ whetherÂ serviceÂ providersÂ receiveÂ 5%Â ofÂ theÂ valueÂ ofÂ theirÂ annualÂ contractÂ (betweenÂ USDÂ 10,000Â andÂ USDÂ 12,500).Â Â

SocialÂ auditsÂ areÂ alsoÂ beingÂ usedÂ asÂ anÂ institutionalizedÂ toolÂ forÂ monitoringÂ programÂ effectivenessÂ inÂ theÂ NationalÂ RuralÂ EmploymentÂ GuaranteeÂ SchemeÂ (NREGS)Â inÂ severalÂ statesÂ inÂ IndiaÂ (ChamorroÂ etÂ al.Â 2010).44Â TheÂ coreÂ ofÂ theÂ socialÂ auditÂ methodÂ isÂ toÂ involve,Â inÂ theÂ processÂ ofÂ auditing,Â theÂ entireÂ groupÂ orÂ communityÂ thatÂ isÂ affectedÂ byÂ theÂ programÂ thatÂ isÂ beingÂ audited.Â InÂ mostÂ cases,Â theÂ membersÂ carryingÂ outÂ theÂ socialÂ auditsÂ areÂ volunteersÂ whoÂ areÂ directlyÂ affectedÂ byÂ theÂ program.Â TheseÂ volunteersÂ areÂ generallyÂ trainedÂ inÂ socialÂ auditÂ processÂ byÂ aÂ NGO/CSO.Â Â

doc.repnme: Rules, roles, and controls : governance in social protection with an application to social assistance
doc.abstracts: The paper develops an operational definition of governance that can be applied to social protection. The 2004 World Development Report (WDR) accountability framework acts as a starting point, defining accountability in terms of a set of principal?agent relationships between policymakers, providers, and citizens. Applying this framework to social protection, the paper looks at three broad areas where the Bank is involved in governance in social protection: rules of the game, including clear criteria for entry and exit of programs; roles and responsibilities, including defining accountability relationships and incentive frameworks across levels of government and institutions involved in social protection; and controls and accountability measures, including the broad set of implementation mechanisms and procedures for ensuring that 'the right benefit gets to the right person at the right time'. The paper applies this framework to social assistance policies and programs, reviews what is currently being done across the Bank in this area, and identifies future opportunities for clients and Bank engagement.
